Users can continue to create new scans until March 9, 2026; after this date, the app will only allow access to existing local files. Microsoft recommends switching to the OneDrive app, but the app lacks the simplicity of the original standalone Lens app. Microsoft placed one of its best apps, Microsoft Lens PDF Scanner, on the chopping block last year. The app was supposed to be removed from the Google Play Store and the Apple App Store in mid-November, and users were supposed to lose the ability to create new scans entirely after mid-December. title: PSA: Hereâ€™s why you shouldnâ€™t let strangers with smart glasses use your phone
summary: It looks like scammers are using smart glasses in a bid to capture IMEI details.
body: Credit: Edgar Cervantes / Android Authority TL;DR A Redditor has shared what appears to be a more sophisticated IMEI scam. The user claimed that a stranger with Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses asked to make a call from their phone, but accessed the deviceâ€™s IMEI number. It almost goes without saying that you shouldnâ€™t let strangers use your phone for any claimed reason. All smartphones have an IMEI number , which is effectively the phoneâ€™s ID number. Unfortunately, cybercriminals and other bad actors often steal IMEI numbers to facilitate crimes. Now, a Redditor has outlined a rather crazy IMEI scam. Redditor Prudent-Vacation-581 reported that a person with Meta Ray-Ban smart glasses recently asked to make a call from their phone. The Redditor reported that the stranger instead dialed *#06#, which reveals the deviceâ€™s IMEI number, gave the phone back, and â€œran away.â€ The user received a pop-up on their phone the following day, noting that the device is now unlocked.

title: Googleâ€™s new checkout protocol lets you buy products without leaving your search results
summary: Googleâ€™s new Universal Commerce Protocol lets AI find, compare, and buy items in one flow.
body: Credit: Joe Maring / Android Authority TL;DR Googleâ€™s new universal checkout protocol aims to complete the purchase for you directly within a Gemini chat or AI search interface. Google built the Universal Commerce Protocol with input from major players like Shopify, Walmart, Target, Etsy, and Wayfair, with more than 20 partners already signed on. The new â€œBusiness Agentsâ€ also let brands answer shopper questions in conversational results using their own product knowledge. Imagine asking your phone for new running shoes, and instead of just getting links, an AI finds and buys them for you, so you donâ€™t have to switch between tabs. That future is now much closer. Google has unveiled a new open-standard framework that aims to make autonomous, AI-led shopping a real part of how we buy things online. At the center of this change is a protocol called Universal Commerce Protocol (UCP). It serves as a common language, enabling AI agents to connect with retailers, payment systems, and shopping platforms without requiring custom connections.

title: I never expected an AI app to replace my keyboard, but I was wrong

title: I found the cutest (and strangest) Android phone at CES 2026
summary: It's two phones in one, or something like that.
body: I know that the Clicks Communicator got a lot of love at CES this year. Honestly, it probably deserves most of it â€” a physical keyboard with a fingerprint reader hidden in the spacebar is a cool design. It wasnâ€™t much of a surprise, though, as weâ€™d heard rumblings about big things out of Clicks leading up to the show. However, as I wandered the show floor on my last day in Las Vegas, I stumbled upon another tiny little Android device, and I think it might have stolen some of the Communicatorâ€™s thunder. Itâ€™s called the Ikko MindOne, and itâ€™s exactly the type of quirky little device I love to find at CES .

title: New year, new me: 5 popular apps Iâ€™m replacing in 2026, and why
summary: The time has come.
body: Credit: Joe Maring / Android Authority I always see the start of every year as a blank piece of paper â€” a chance to start fresh. And thatâ€™s exactly what Iâ€™ll be doing this year when it comes to the apps and services I use. I regularly use several of them, but itâ€™s time to make changes for two reasons. The first is that some of these apps simply donâ€™t serve me anymore, whether due to a lack of functionality or a price point thatâ€™s become too high. The second is that switching to a new app Iâ€™ll use regularly is actually a fun process for me. It gives me that boost of energy I need to kick off the year on the right note.

title: Nothing is finally ditching Lock Glimpse, but one model has to wait
summary: The Phone 3a Lite still has Lock Glimpse.
body: TL;DR The December Nothing OS update removes Lock Glimpse from Nothing Phone 3a and 3a Pro. Nothing Phone 3a Lite still has Lock Glimpse installed, but it can be disabled. Nothing says a future update will let Phone 3a Lite users uninstall Lock Glimpse. Nothing phones started getting Android 16 with the rollout of Nothing OS 4.0 in November . On Nothing Phone 3a, 3a Pro , and 3a Lite, the update included a feature called Lock Glimpse, a widely panned addition that served ads on those phonesâ€™ lock screens. Now, Nothing has announced that itâ€™s bowing to user pressure and removing the feature â€” at least on the 3a and 3a Pro. Lock Glimpse has always been an optional feature, technically â€” 3a series phones on Nothing OS 4.0 present the option to disable it. That solution wasnâ€™t satisfactory, though, as users found the software was draining their batteries even when turned off . Today, Nothing shared that the feature is being removed from the 3a series (except the 3a Lite) as of the Nothing OS 4.0 December update.

title: Honorâ€™s slim Magic 8 Pro variant officially has a launch date, and itâ€™s soon
summary: Honor's upcoming thin smartphone looks like an iPhone Air clone.
body: TL;DR Honor launched the Magic 8 Pro and Lite in the UK, but another Magic 8 series phone is launching soon. The company confirmed the Honor Magic 8 Pro Air, a slimmer Magic 8 Pro variant, will be unveiled on January 19. Honor is taking pre-reservations for the Magic 8 Pro Air in 256GB, 512GB, and 1TB configurations in China. Honor officially launched the Honor Magic 8 Pro and Magic 8 Lite in the UK this week, with the former being a true flagship and the latter striking a more affordable price point. The Honor Magic 8 Pro brings impressive specs such as a 200MP telephoto camera, the Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite Gen 5 chipset , and a 6,270mAh battery capacity. However, Honor is already gearing up to launch another Magic 8 Pro variant, and it now has an official launch date. Recent teasers and rumors pointed toward Honor launching an ultra-slim version of the Magic 8 Pro, and the company confirmed in a Weibo post that this device will launch later this month as the Magic 8 Pro Air. The handset will be revealed on January 19 in China, which is less than two weeks away. The launch teaser video doesnâ€™t reveal much about the Magic 8 Pro Air, instead comparing the power and thinness of tâ€¦

title: Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses can now single out a voice in a nosy crowd
summary: SAY AGAIN?
body: TL;DR Meta is rolling out its conversation focus smart glasses feature in early access. Conversation focus is meant to amplify the voice of the person youâ€™re talking to to make conversation easier in noisy environments. The feature is available to try on Ray-Ban Meta and Oakley Meta HSTN glasses. Most smart glasses arenâ€™t explicitly made to be accessibility tools, but itâ€™s easy to imagine ways they could be used to that end. Take Metaâ€™s conversation focus, which uses smart glassesâ€™ built-in speakers to amplify the voice of the person youâ€™re talking to in noisy environments. The feature was announced months ago, but now, itâ€™s rolling out in a limited test. Meta announced its conversation focus feature at the companyâ€™s Connect event in September, and users have been able to sign up for a waitlist to try it since December. UploadVR spotted today that the feature is actually making its way to users whoâ€™ve signed up for Metaâ€™s Early Access program.

title: I tried the AI camera that watches you while you eat, and itâ€™s as weird as it sounds
summary: Between this and smart fitness glasses, Amazfit came prepared to CES 2026.
body: One of my favorite things about CES is the opportunity to see wild concept devices. Not all of these are home runs (such as Razerâ€™s AI anime girlfriend speaker ), but theyâ€™re still fascinating glimpses into what some companies see as the future of consumer tech. Health/fitness brand Amazfit has two such concept devices at CES 2026 â€” the V1TAL Food Camera and Helio Smart Glasses â€” and I had the opportunity to try both. The V1TAL is easily the most polarizing of the two, so letâ€™s start there. I saw the V1TAL behind closed doors at last yearâ€™s CES, but this was the first time I could photograph it and see it more thoroughly. As for what it is, itâ€™s exactly as I describe in the headline: an AI camera that watches you while you eat.

title: This is our first look at how Samsung will save Bixby
summary: Samsung's rumored Bixby reboot with Perplexity AI has been revealed in detailed One UI 8.5 leak.
body: Credit: Andy Walker / Android Authority TL;DR Bixby could be getting a real AI upgrade in One UI 8.5 by handing complex questions to Perplexity AI. We now have our first visual proof that Perplexity AI is Bixbyâ€™s new brain. A new Bixby Live interface hints at real-time AI conversations, mirroring Gemini Live capabilities. Samsungâ€™s Bixby has spent the better part of the decade being the assistant we love to disable, but the new One UI 8.5 update could make that decision harder. Rather than competing directly with Google Gemini, Samsung is reportedly following Appleâ€™s lead by bringing in stronger AI support . We now have a detailed look at how Perplexity AI will supercharge Bixby to handle more complex tasks. Leaker @GalaxyTechie shared plenty of screenshots on X showing an early version of One UI 8.5 (via SamMobile ). In these images, Bixby sends complex questions to Perplexity instead of using its own limited knowledge. The responses look more like well-researched answers, complete with citations.

title: Fans blow. Could tiny speakers be a smarter way to cool down devices?
summary: An ultrasonic "fan on a chip" could be the next big breakthrough in mobile cooling.
body: TL;DR xMEMS is showing off its ÂµCooling system that uses ultrasonic speakers to move air. The system is silent, water-resistant, and can small enough to be used in wearables. A ducted ÂµCooling solution for phones could move up to 0.1 cubic feet of air a minute. Heat is arguably the biggest enemy of modern processors. We can build incredibly fast chips, but run them too fast, and theyâ€™re going to start to melt down. As a result, nearly every device we use has to make some sort of balance between performance and thermal emissions. This year at CES in Las Vegas , weâ€™re learning about an innovative new way that xMEMS is trying to tackle that problem, giving even compact mobile devices another option for staying cool. Donâ€™t want to miss the best from Android Authority ?

title: Hereâ€™s how youâ€™ll finally be able to set up your own Calling Card on Android
summary: Google is solving the biggest Calling Card complaint on Android.
body: TL;DR Weâ€™ve managed to enable the upcoming â€œMy Calling Cardâ€ feature in Googleâ€™s Phone app. You can now create your own Calling Card, choose a photo, customize fonts, and control who sees it. If someone hasnâ€™t customized your card already, theyâ€™ll see your version when you call. Google introduced Calling Cards for Android last year. Just like iOS, Calling Card on Android lets you customize how incoming calls from friends and family appear on your phone. Itâ€™s a great feature, but has been lacking something big Apple offers with Contact Posters on iPhones since the feature came around. While you can customize how other peopleâ€™s Calling Cards look on your device, you canâ€™t control how your own Calling Card appears when calling other people. In October, we reported that Google is about to fix this limitation. We found that Google is working on a new â€œMy calling cardâ€ option inside the Phone by Google app to allow you to set up your own Calling Card that would appear for other users when you call them. At the time, the setting existed, but it didnâ€™t actually do anything. Now, we can show you exactly how youâ€™ll be able to set up your own calling card.
